appearances.snippet: nsrp chairman marky mark mario diaz-balart took decisive action to reprioritize funding in support of our nation's security. this has allowed us to eliminate 9.3 billion in spending, while reasserting deterrence and leadership to protect the safety, freedom and prosperity of the american people. we show that focused strategy, not endless spending, is what delivers results. we make critical investments in high impact initiatives that combatant narcotic narcotics and human trafficking confront the malign influence of the chinese communist party and counterterrorism. we reinforce democracy and human rights efforts and defend religious liberty as both a moral duty and vital american interest. we will not tolerate religious persecution and attacks on faith. upholding those values strengthens american leadership and advances freedom around the world. we also eliminate wasteful initiatives, implement the necessary accountability at the united nations, and prohibit any funds for things like unra or the taliban. bottom line we counter our foes and stand with our friends and ensure investments

appearances.snippet: . >> house republican mario diaz-balart posted a full throated endorsement of what happened overnight. let me read it. today's action, ordered by president trump, is what decisive leadership truly looks like. our country has faced an unprecedented national security threat from the illegitimate maduro regime, unabated. for years, maduro sent drugs into our country, killing an untold number of americans, kidnaped innocent americans, flooded our country with violent cartel members from tren de aragua and the cartel de las olas, while destabilizing regional security. and the statement goes on, we should also say that there are americans here, many of them in florida, who will celebrate the end of, maduro's leadership there, if not the end of of the regime. but let's also focus on what we're hearing, likely from some people who have come to this country who are happy that maduro is out. >> absolutely. and i think that you know, the president understands that especially when you frame this in the the frame of, of narco terrorism and the drug trafficking. i think that they think that that is

appearances.title: Way Too Early With Ali Vitali : MSNOW : January 16, 2026 2:00am-3:01am PST
appearances.snippet: i mean, members like mario diaz-balart has strong ties to machado and says that, you know, we need to recognize the opposition leaders here. at the same time, the white house feels like in rodriguez, it's someone they can work with, and they're pointing to some of the steps that rodriguez has taken so far. you know, in terms of oil, in terms of starting to begin the process of releasing prisoners. but it's important to note rodriguez is under sanctions. we don't have relationships. we don't have. we don't formally recognize venezuela. and there's really no timetable for free and fair elections. so, you know, there's just a tremendous amount of jockeying for influence and power here. rodriguez sent one of her envoys to washington, and she really pulled almost a putin. she set up a phone call with trump the day before machado's meeting. so she got into his ear. so, you know, i don't think we come out of this meeting with machado with really any change to the status quo. i mean, she entered the white the white house with a nobel prize. she left with a swag bag. she was spotted carrying a

appearances.snippet: that house republicans from florida are playing on this issue, one of them being congressman mario diaz-balarte was questioned about his support. >> wait. hold on, hold on a second. first, you're talking to us. when ever not supported? no no no no no wait wait wait. but let's look. these are elections that the next democratically elected president of venezuela is going to be. maria corina machado. >> i actually think that might be the place where a rift actually be put in power next. so what is that dichotomy that we're looking at? >> i that's incredibly, incredibly interesting. it's probably in congress overall who has spoken. who, by the way, comes from a prominent cuban family, involved in these issues for a very long time. >> and where the republican fault lines might be, i think that is probably one of the ones that is the most interesting and impactful on the ground in venezuela. jake sherman, thank you. right here on mbs. now our cov nicolas maduro? moros? maduro responded in spanish.

appearances.title: Morning Joe : MSNOW : January 15, 2026 3:00am-7:00am PST
appearances.snippet: it's people like mario diaz-balart and senator rick scott who you just saw on the screen.the same time, these are people with deep relationships with machado. they've continued their conversations with her in this interim two week period, and there is such a clarity that they see her as the next democratic leader, the leader that they want in this transition. and you kind of look no further than the way that trump muddied the waters, seemed to say she didn't have the respect to take on leadership in the country. and in the immediate days after mario diaz-balart was part of a press conference in south florida where a reporter asked, well, is there u.s. support for machado and diaz-balart cut him off. before he could even finish the question, he said, whoa, whoa, whoa. when have we ever not been supportive of machado? and so trump is going to have his meeting today. they have high hopes for it. but if he doesn't come out with this same clarity, there could be a rift here brewing. it's not there yet, though. >> republicans are optimistic he will come around to that position a

appearances.title: Ana Cabrera Reports : MSNOW : January 15, 2026 7:00am-9:00am PST
appearances.snippet: this is an administration, as mario diaz-balart, the congressman from florida, reminded me, that is fullal, pam bondi, to the secretary of state to the un ambassador and mike wallace, there is a lot of knowledge and a lot of focus on venezuela. and it's in part why rubio has been so good at being able to steer in the direction he wants to on this issue. paula, to have these two. venezuelan women trying to curry favor with this american president, a foreign leader who is set to ultimately maybe determine the future of their country? i mean, how significant is this? >> i mean, it's all so full of contradictions, right? that i think that's what kind of scares me that that in these conversations, it's starting to sound like a telenovela. right? and we're kind of losing the meaning of what democracy means, what liberty means, what freedoms mean. you're right. the idea that 2000 miles away from caracas, the president of the united states, is somehow dictating the fate of venezuela? it's kind of absurd, but i think venezuelans right now are feeling that they are closer to the illusion of democr
